title: Finite Sums of a Set
content: The set finiteSums(A) consists of all natural numbers that can be expressed as the sum of a finite set of distinct elements from A. Formally, n ∈ finiteSums(A) iff there exists a finite S ⊆ A with n = Σₛ s. This includes 0 (the empty sum) and all individual elements.

title: Complete Sequences
content: A set A is complete if every sufficiently large natural number lies in finiteSums(A). Formally, ∃N such that ∀n ≥ N, n ∈ finiteSums(A). This allows finitely many exceptions below the threshold N. Classic examples include the powers of 2 and the Fibonacci numbers.

title: Strongly Complete Sequences
content: A stronger notion requires representing ALL natural numbers, not just those above a threshold. This is the 'strong completeness' Van Doorn's theorem addresses. The distinction matters: strong completeness imposes stricter constraints on robustness.

title: Removing Indices
content: To remove elements from a sequence a : ℕ → ℕ, we specify a finite set S of indices to exclude. The resulting set is {a(i) : i ∉ S}. This models 'removing m elements' as choosing m indices and excluding them from the sequence.

title: m-Robustness
content: A sequence is m-robust if it remains complete after removing ANY set of m indices. This is a universally quantified property: for all S with |S| = m, the remaining sequence is still complete. Higher robustness means more resilience to deletions.

title: Not n-Robust
content: A sequence is NOT n-robust if there EXISTS some set of n indices whose removal breaks completeness. This is existentially quantified: we only need one 'bad' set of n elements. The problem asks for sequences that are m-robust but not n-robust.

title: Valid Pairs
content: A pair (m, n) with m < n is valid if there exists a monotone, complete sequence that is m-robust but not n-robust. The set of all such pairs is what Problem #348 asks us to characterize. Known valid pairs are (0,1) and (1,2).

title: Powers of 2
content: The sequence 2^n = 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, ... is complete because every positive integer has a unique binary representation. It's the prototypical complete sequence. Every natural number can be written as a sum of distinct powers of 2.

title: The Fibonacci Sequence
content: We use the shifted Fibonacci sequence 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, ... (starting F₀=1, F₁=2). This is complete by Zeckendorf's theorem: every positive integer is uniquely a sum of non-consecutive Fibonacci numbers. It's also 1-robust but not 2-robust.

title: Powers of 2 are Complete
content: Every positive integer has a binary representation, which is a sum of distinct powers of 2. This is the fundamental theorem of binary arithmetic. The representation is unique, giving exactly one way to write each number.

title: Powers of 2 are Not 1-Robust
content: Removing any power 2^k breaks completeness. Specifically, the number 2^k itself can no longer be represented: it's not a sum of other powers of 2 (since binary representation is unique). This shows the sequence is 0-robust but not 1-robust.

title: (0, 1) is Valid
content: Powers of 2 witness that (0, 1) ∈ validPairs. The sequence is trivially 0-robust (removing nothing preserves everything) and not 1-robust (removing any element breaks completeness). This is the simplest non-trivial valid pair.

title: Fibonacci is Complete
content: Zeckendorf's theorem (1972) states that every positive integer has a unique representation as a sum of non-consecutive Fibonacci numbers. This makes the Fibonacci sequence complete. The non-consecutivity condition ensures uniqueness.

title: Fibonacci is 1-Robust
content: Removing any single Fibonacci number doesn't break completeness. The remaining Fibonacci numbers can still represent all large integers. The proof uses the flexibility in Zeckendorf representations—alternative representations exist.

title: Fibonacci is Not 2-Robust
content: Removing F₀=1 and F₁=2 breaks completeness: the number 3 cannot be represented. With 1 and 2 removed, the smallest available elements are 3, 5, 8, ... and 3 itself cannot be written as a sum of these (3 alone works, but any sum of 5,8,... is ≥ 5).

title: (1, 2) is Valid
content: The Fibonacci sequence witnesses that (1, 2) ∈ validPairs. It's 1-robust (survives any single deletion) but not 2-robust (deleting 1 and 2 breaks it). This is the second known valid pair after (0, 1).

title: Characterization Conjecture
content: The full characterization of valid pairs is unknown. One possibility: valid pairs are exactly {(m, m+1) : m ∈ ℕ}. Another: there's a cutoff k beyond which (m, m+1) is not valid. Determining which is true is the essence of Problem #348.

title: The (2, 3) Case
content: Whether (2, 3) is valid remains unknown. Finding a sequence that is 2-robust but not 3-robust would prove it valid. Alternatively, proving no such sequence exists would establish a barrier at m = 2. This is the key open case.

title: Van Doorn's Theorem
content: Wouter van Doorn proved that for STRONGLY complete sequences (representing ALL integers), no sequence is 2-robust. This rules out (2, n) for any n > 2 under strong completeness. The weak completeness case remains open.

title: Representation Count
content: The representation count r(A, n) counts how many ways n can be written as a sum of distinct elements of A. Completeness is equivalent to r(A, n) > 0 for all large n. Studying r(A, n) gives finer information about the additive structure.

title: The Gap Property
content: The gap between consecutive terms a(n+1) - a(n) must be bounded for complete sequences. If gaps grow unboundedly, integers in the gap cannot be represented. This structural constraint limits which sequences can be complete.

title: Main Open Problem
content: The core question: are all pairs (m, m+1) valid, or is there a cutoff? The first option means every robustness level has a 'tight' example. The second means beyond some point, m-robustness automatically implies (m+1)-robustness. Both possibilities are consistent with current knowledge.
